article:
I was doing a big clean-up one day and my kids were helping. One of my sons 36 came across  a knotted   handkerchief with an old dark brown coin in it. "Mum, can I have this?" he asked. I took one look and was immediately   _   to another time. "No," I said slowly. "This one's   _  ." 
My son looked at me   _   and I explained. In 1991, I had spent five months in an African country, Niger. There were things I found terrible about this place--the heat and   _  . Street urchins   would continually thrust   their hands into your face,   _   "Cadeau! Cadeau!" ("gift" in French). 
Then, I went to neighboring Burkina Faso by taxi.   _   I began to unload, a man grabbed my daypack and disappeared in the darkness.
The bag had my passport, money and other things   _   to me. I was in deep trouble. In the following weeks, I regarded all locals with suspicion  . 
Walking through Burkina's streets one day, I was   _   rudely by an old woman who thrust her hand in my face. "Cadeau! Cadeau!" she cried. 
I'd had enough. I was sick and   _   of the country: its poverty, its thieves, the heat. I told her 46 _  in French, "I have no 'cadeau'. A thief stole all my money. I cannot give you anything."
The beggar woman thought carefully about my   _  . Then she smiled as she   _   into the folds of her dress. 
"I will give you a cadeau." She   _   an old, dark brown coin in my palm kindly. I looked at it in   _  . It was a very small amount of money--but for her, the coin 51 _  a meal. I realized she had given me a   _   disproportionate   to anything that I had ever donated. In the midst of her   _  , she was able to give me something   _  . 
I saw then the unexpected   _   of the people of Burkina Faso. I hope never to part with the coin the old woman gave me.
